newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 48-year-old woman has a 4-day history of pruritic rash on her legs.  The lesions initially worsened rapidly over 1-2 hours, and some lesions resolved by the end of the day.  The lesions recurred several times over the past 2-3 days, with each episode lasting 6-8 hours.  Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 138/77 mm Hg, and pulse is 78/min.  Skin examination findings are shown in the exhibit.  The remainder of the physical examination is normal.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Acute urticaria

Etiologies

  • Medications, insect stings
  • Infections, rheumatologic diseases
  • Many cases are idiopathic

Pathophysiology

  • Mast cells release histamine → dermal edema

Clinical features

  • Pruritic, erythematous plaques (ie, wheals)
  • Each wheal lasts <24 hr, urticaria duration <6 weeks
  • Diffuse or localized

Evaluation

  • No workup for 1st episode
  • Allergy testing if specific trigger (eg, food) is suspected
  • Laboratory testing/biopsy if systemic symptoms are present

Treatment & prognosis

  • 2nd-generation H1 antihistamines
  • Add H2 antihistamines or systemic corticosteroids if severe
  • Two-thirds of cases self-resolve

This patient has acute urticaria, intensely pruritic, well-circumscribed erythematous plaques (ie, wheals) caused by mast cell activation in the superficial dermis.  Urticaria lesions can be round or serpiginous and up to several centimeters in diameter.  Although individual lesions develop over minutes to hours and resolve within 24 hours, additional lesions may continue to erupt for up to 6 weeks.  Angioedema, which is caused by mast cell activation in the deeper dermal and subcutaneous tissues (eg, face, lips, hands, buttocks), sometimes accompanies urticaria.

Acute urticaria usually represents an IgE-mediated allergic reaction (eg, medications, insect bites, food); additional etiologies include infection (eg, bacterial, viral) and systemic illness (eg, rheumatologic disorder, mastocytosis); many cases are idiopathic.  Initial management includes a second-generation H1 blocker (eg, cetirizine).  A single episode typically requires no additional evaluation, although laboratory evaluation and biopsy are recommended for episodes that are unresponsive to therapy or accompanied by systemic symptoms (eg, arthritis).

(Choice A)  Acute atopic dermatitis presents with erythematous papules and vesicles, not wheals, that are typically distributed over the flexural areas (eg, antecubital fossae) rather than extensor surfaces.  Individual lesions persist for days to weeks and are not transient.

(Choice B)  Contact dermatitis is caused by contact with irritants or allergens that acutely cause pruritic, erythematous papules or vesicles that last for days to weeks.  Rapid resolution within a day is not typical.

(Choice C)  Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited condition likely caused by a viral etiology.  It begins as a solitary herald patch that appears pink on light skin and violet to brown on darker skin.  The appearance of this patch is followed by eruption of multiple ovoid papules and plaques with a collarette of scales on the trunk and proximal extremities.  Individual lesions usually take 4-6 weeks to resolve.

(Choice E)  Viral exanthem is usually associated with fever and other symptoms (eg, cough, diarrhea) of a viral illness.  It presents with nonpruritic, erythematous macules and papules that last for days.

Educational objective:
Acute urticaria presents with intensely pruritic, well-circumscribed erythematous plaques (ie, wheals).  Individual lesions resolve within 24 hours, but additional lesions may erupt for up to 6 weeks.  Angioedema sometimes accompanies urticaria.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 35-year-old man presents with progressive skin lesions over the past 3 weeks.  The lesions are not painful or itchy.  He has no other symptoms.  The patient underwent kidney transplantation 3 months ago for glomerulonephritis, and his postoperative course was complicated by mild graft rejection, which required treatment with high-dose corticosteroids.  Vital signs are normal.  The oral mucosa has no lesions.  There are multiple red, nontender lesions localized to the trunk and lower extremities.  One of the lesions is seen in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Kaposi sarcoma

Type

Risk group

Features

Classic

  • Mediterranean or Central/Eastern European
  • Age >60
  • Indolent
  • Visceral lesions rare

Endemic

  • Equatorial Africa
  • Indolent or aggressive
  • Visceral lesions can occur

Iatrogenic

  • Immunosuppression
  • Particularly after organ transplantation
  • Can be aggressive
  • Visceral lesions common
  • Usually improves when immunosuppressives reduced

AIDS

  • Men who have sex with men
  • CD4 <200/mm3
  • Can be aggressive
  • Visceral lesions common
  • Usually improves with antiretroviral therapy

This patient underwent organ transplantation and subsequently required high-dose corticosteroids due to graft rejection.  Glucocorticoids block synthesis of proinflammatory cytokines and broadly inhibit the immune response, leading to increased risk of opportunistic infections.  In this case, the patient developed several red lesions that are not itchy or painful, suggesting Kaposi sarcoma, a highly angiogenic endothelial tumor caused by reactivation of human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8).

Kaposi sarcoma, which is commonly associated with AIDS, is also common in patients on high-dose immunosuppressive therapy after organ transplantation.  Those who develop the malignancy usually do so within the first year.  The lesions usually begin as flat purple marks that may be mistaken for a bruise that does not heal.  They then progress to violaceous, brown, or red papules that are usually not painful, pruritic, or necrotic.  Lymphedema distal to the lesions is common.  Patients who develop Kaposi sarcoma after organ transplantation are at high risk for visceral lesions, primarily in the lung or gastrointestinal tract.

The diagnosis is usually made based on clinical appearance, but biopsy is occasionally required.  Reduction in immunosuppressive therapy often leads to spontaneous resolution, but local or systemic therapy is occasionally required.

(Choice A)  Hemangioma is a vascular tumor most common in infancy.  This patient's development of multiple lesions over a short period of time in adulthood makes hemangioma unlikely.

(Choice C)  Malignant melanoma can sometimes resemble a purple Kaposi sarcoma lesion; however, malignant melanoma tends to form over a much longer period of time.  It does not usually cause multiple cutaneous lesions at the same time over a short period.

(Choice D)  Squamous cell carcinoma typically arises on areas of skin that receive excessive sun exposure.  They appear as a nodule, plaque, or papule that is smooth, hyperkeratotic, or ulcerated.  The presence of multiple lesions over a short period of time makes this diagnosis unlikely.

(Choice E)  Superficial basal cell carcinoma is a locally invasive tumor that typically occurs on the face or trunk.  It usually appears as a flesh- or pink-colored papule, but occasionally black pigment may be present.  However, the presence of multiple lesions in a short period makes this unlikely.

Educational objective:
Patients who are on high-dose immunosuppressive therapy after organ transplantation are at high risk for developing Kaposi sarcoma, an endothelial tumor associated with reactivation of human herpesvirus 8.  Lesions typically arise within the first year of therapy and appear as multiple violaceous, red, or brown papules that do not itch or cause pain.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 42-year-old man has a pruritic rash that began 3 months ago and has since enlarged and spread across his back, chest, and abdomen.  The patient has attempted treatment with topical emollients and over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream without relief.  Examination reveals scaly, annular plaques, as shown in the exhibit.  Potassium hydroxide microscopy of skin scrapings from one of the lesions shows segmented hyphae.  Which of the of the following laboratory studies should be obtained in this patient?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Risk factors for dermatophyte infection

Environmental exposures

  • Warm, humid environments
  • Direct contact with infected person, fomites, or public showers
  • Contact with animals (eg, kittens)

Patient factors

  • Concurrent dermatophyte infection (autoinoculation)
  • Occlusive clothing
  • Obesity
  • Peripheral artery disease

Immune deficiency

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • HIV infection
  • Systemic glucocorticoid therapy

This patient has a chronic skin rash characterized by confluent, scaly, annular plaques.  The potassium hydroxide preparation confirms the diagnosis of tinea corporis.  Tinea corporis, sometimes called ringworm, is a superficial dermatophyte infection caused by Trichophyton rubrum or similar species.  The fungi thrive in warm, moist areas (eg, shower surfaces, pools, gymnasium mats) and can be transmitted by skin-to-skin contact or contact with animals (eg, cats) or via fomites.

Patients with tinea corporis are at risk for developing additional foci of infection elsewhere on the body, toes (tinea pedis), groin (tinea cruris), or nails (tinea unguium/onychomycosis) due to autoinoculation.  However, extensive, widespread involvement, as in this patient, should raise concern for compromised immunity.  Possible contributing factors include diabetes mellitus, systemic glucocorticoid therapy, and HIV infection.  In addition to appropriate screening studies, this patient should receive systemic (eg, oral fluconazole) rather than topical antifungal therapy (as would be appropriate for limited, localized disease).

(Choice A)  Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus can present with confluent, annular plaques on the upper body.  However, it predominantly involves sun-exposed skin, and itching is uncommon.

(Choice B)  Skin disorders suggesting underlying hepatitis C include porphyria cutanea tarda (erythema and bullae in sun-exposed areas), lichen planus (pruritic, pink/purple papules and plaques predominantly located at wrists and ankles), and leukocytoclastic vasculitis (palpable purpura).

(Choice D)  Secondary syphilis is associated with a macular-papular rash that can be scaly but typically involves nearly the entire body, including the palms and soles.

(Choice E)  Selective IgA deficiency is the most common primary immune deficiency.  Most patients are asymptomatic, although they are at increased risk for gastrointestinal and respiratory infections.  The risk of dermatophyte infections is not appreciably increased.

Educational objective:
Patients with tinea corporis are at risk for developing additional foci of infection elsewhere on the body, toes, groin, or nails due to autoinoculation.  Patients with compromised immunity due to diabetes mellitus, systemic glucocorticoid therapy, or HIV infection can develop extensive, widespread involvement.

(Choice B)  Skin disorders suggesting underlying hepatitis C include porphyria cutanea tarda (erythema and bullae in sun-exposed areas), lichen planus (pruritic, pink/purple papules and plaques predominantly located at wrists and ankles), and leukocytoclastic vasculitis (palpable purpura).

(Choice D)  Secondary syphilis is associated with a macular-papular rash that can be scaly but typically involves nearly the entire body, including the palms and soles.

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 42-year-old man has a pruritic rash that began 3 months ago and has since enlarged and spread across his back, chest, and abdomen.  The patient has attempted treatment with topical emollients and over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream without relief.  Examination reveals scaly, annular plaques, as shown in the exhibit.  Potassium hydroxide microscopy of skin scrapings from one of the lesions shows segmented hyphae.  Which of the of the following laboratory studies should be obtained in this patient?

  • Obesity
  • Peripheral artery disease

  • HIV infection
  • Systemic glucocorticoid therapy

newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 60-year-old woman with Parkinson disease in long-term care is found to have a rash on the face, scalp, and area behind the ears, which she says has been present for several months.  The rash is mildly itchy but not painful.  The patient has not used new skin care or cosmetic products.  Her other medical conditions include hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Physical examination findings are shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's rash?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Seborrheic dermatitis in adults

Pathogenesis

  • Possibly related to Malassezia colonization & associated inflammation

Clinical features

  • Erythematous, pruritic plaques with greasy scales
  • Scalp, central face, ears, chest

Risk factors

  • CNS disease (eg, Parkinson disease)
  • HIV

Treatment

  • Topical antifungals (eg, selenium sulfide, ketoconazole)
  • Topical glucocorticoids*
  • Maintenance treatment required to prevent recurrence

*Low-potency glucocorticoids should be used in areas with thin skin (eg, face).

This patient has seborrheic dermatitis, which presents with erythematous patches and plaques with greasy scales.  Seborrheic dermatitis often affects areas with a high density of sebaceous glands, including the central face (eg, eyebrows, nasolabial folds), ears, and scalp (dandruff); less common locations include the chest, back, axillae, and inguinal area.  Seborrheic dermatitis is most common in the first year of life and again in adulthood.  Seborrheic dermatitis (including extensive disease) occurs more frequently in patients with CNS disorders (eg, Parkinson disease, stroke) or HIV.  The diagnosis is made clinically.

The pathogenesis of seborrheic dermatitis is unclear, but Malassezia fungal species (which are part of normal skin flora) may play a role, possibly by promoting inflammation.  Topical antifungal agents (eg, ketoconazole, selenium sulfide) and/or topical corticosteroid therapy effectively treat this condition.  Low-potency corticosteroid therapy is preferred over high-potency corticosteroid therapy in areas with thin skin (eg, face) to minimize risk for dermal atrophy (Choice C).  Because recurrence is common, periodic maintenance treatment is often required.

(Choice A)  Oral antifungals (eg, terbinafine, itraconazole) are commonly used to treat extensive or refractory fungal skin infections, such as tinea faciei, which presents with erythematous, scaly, annular plaques on the face.  These drugs can be considered for treating widespread or refractory seborrheic dermatitis, but topical agents are preferred initially due to their established effectiveness and lesser toxicity.

(Choice B)  Topical emollients treat xerosis (dry skin), which causes mild scaling in indistinct patches.  Unlike seborrheic dermatitis, which typically affects areas rich in sebaceous glands (ie, central face), xerosis tends to manifest in areas with sparse sebaceous glands (eg, extremities).

(Choice E)  Topical metronidazole is appropriate for papulopustular rosacea, which presents with erythematous papules and pustules on the face; these lesions are not present in this patient.

Educational objective:
Seborrheic dermatitis presents with erythematous patches and plaques with greasy scales, most commonly on the central face, ears, and scalp.  It is more common in patients with HIV and CNS disorders (eg, Parkinson disease).  Diagnosis is made clinically, and topical antifungal therapy (eg, ketoconazole, selenium sulfide) is an effective treatment.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Family medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for a rash on both thighs for the past 3 weeks.  The rash started as areas of redness with pruritus.  In the past week, the pruritus has intensified, and numerous blisters have developed on the medial thighs.  An over-the-counter oral antihistamine has provided no relief.  There are no mouth sores and there has been no eye discomfort, weight loss, or diarrhea.  Medical history includes hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and early Parkinson disease.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 125/83 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min.  Skin examination is shown in the exhibit.  Punch biopsies are performed.  Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy pending biopsy results?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Bullous pemphigoid

Clinical
features

  • Age >60
  • Pruritic, tense bullae
  • Rare mucosal involvement
  • Prodrome of eczematous/urticaria-like rash

Associated

disorders

  • Dementia
  • Parkinson disease
  • Depression, bipolar disorder

Diagnosis

  • Histology: subepidermal cleavage
  • Immunofluorescence: linear IgG/C3 deposition along basement membrane
  • Serology: autoantibodies to bullous pemphigoid antigens (hemidesmosomes)

Treatment

  • Topical therapies: high-potency corticosteroids
  • Systemic therapies: corticosteroid, doxycycline

This patient with pruritic bullae most likely has bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disorder.  Bullous pemphigoid is most common in patients age >60, with an increased risk in those with neurologic disorders (eg, Parkinson disease).  As seen in this patient, a prodromal phase of pruritic, eczematous, or urticarial-like rash can last weeks to months, followed by the development of tense bullae, which may rupture to form erosions.  Bullous pemphigoid can be localized or diffuse, involving the trunk, extremities, axillae, and inguinal folds.  Unlike pemphigus vulgaris, mucous membrane involvement is rare in bullous pemphigoid, and pruritus, not pain, accompanies the rash.

Regardless of whether empiric therapy is initiated to alleviate severe pruritus, the diagnosis must be confirmed with skin biopsy (eg, light microscopy, direct immunofluorescence) because therapy is often chronic and can involve agents with significant toxicity (eg, systemic corticosteroids).  Serology for antibodies against bullous pemphigoid antigens can further support the diagnosis.

First-line treatment for bullous pemphigoid is a high-potency topical corticosteroid (eg, clobetasol), which is effective even for extensive disease.  If systemic therapy is preferred, oral doxycycline or an oral corticosteroid can be used, although the latter is not as effective as topical corticosteroids.

(Choices A and B)  Dermatitis herpetiformis associated with celiac disease is an autoimmune cutaneous eruption caused by gluten sensitivity; however, the eruption is typically not accompanied by a prodromal phase, and papulovesicular lesions, not bullae, are characteristic.  A combination of a gluten-free diet and dapsone use (also a second-line corticosteroid-sparing agent for bullous pemphigoid that is not routinely used) can quickly induce remission.

(Choice C)  Oral valacyclovir is used to treat herpes zoster, which presents with grouped vesicles on erythematous bases in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.  The rash is associated with burning, neuropathic pain, rather than pruritus.

(Choice E)  Topical clotrimazole is used to treat tinea corporis, which presents with a pruritic, annular, scaly plaque with raised borders.  While this patient's bullae arose from urticarial patches, they lack features of tinea corporis.

Educational objective:
Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically occurs in patients age >60.  It is characterized by pruritic, tense bullae preceded by a prodrome of eczematous or urticarial rash.  The diagnosis requires skin biopsy.  First-line treatment is a high-potency topical corticosteroid, which is effective even for extensive disease.

Clinical

(Choice C)  Oral valacyclovir is used to treat herpes zoster, which presents with grouped vesicles on erythematous bases in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.  The rash is associated with burning, neuropathic pain, rather than pruritus.

(Choice E)  Tinea corporis presents with a pruritic, annular, scaly plaque that can sometimes be accompanied by vesicles and bullae (ie, tinea corporis bullosa).  However, this patient's bullae arose from urticarial patches that lack features of tinea corporis.

newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 17-year-old boy has a rash that has been present for a month.  Multiple light patches appeared on the patient's face, chest, back, and arms while he attended a week-long swim camp.  The patient bought a new sunscreen to prevent burning and applied it 30 minutes before swimming in the camp's pool.  The spots did not tan even though the surrounding skin did somewhat.  The patient says the spots are mildly pruritic but not painful.  Vital signs are normal.  The rash is shown in the exhibit.  Some spots have slight scaling and are nontender.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor)

Pathogenesis

  • Superficial skin infection by Malassezia species
  • Commensal fungus converts to pathogenic filamentous form with exposure to hot & humid environments

Clinical features

  • Hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous macules
  • Distribution: trunk & upper extremities in adolescents & adults, face in children
  • ± Fine scale, pruritus

Diagnosis

  • Clinical
  • KOH preparation: hyphae & yeast cells in a spaghetti-&-meatballs pattern

Treatment

  • Topical ketoconazole, terbinafine, or selenium sulfide

KOH = potassium hydroxide.

This patient has a well-demarcated, hypopigmented rash on the upper trunk that does not tan with sun exposure, a presentation consistent with tinea versicolor.  Tinea versicolor is a superficial skin infection caused by Malasseziaspecies.  These fungi convert to pathogenic forms with heat and humidity; transient melanocyte damage to affected areas results in tanning of only surrounding areas with sun exposure, most apparent in the summer.

TV manifests as well-demarcated macules that can be hyperpigmented, hypopigmented, or erythematous (hence the name "versicolor"); they may coalesce and are often covered with fine scales.  Tinea versicolor commonly affects the upper trunk and extremities, likely due to higher sebum production of these areas, and mild pruritus can occur.  The diagnosis of tinea versicolor is often clinical but can be confirmed with potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scrapings showing hyphae and yeast (spaghetti-and-meatballs appearance).

Management includes topical ketoconazole, which has a direct antifungal effect by limiting the production of a fungal cell membrane component via inhibition of a cytochrome P450 enzyme.  Alternate therapies include topical selenium sulfide or terbinafine.

(Choice A)  Impetigo is a superficial bacterial infection characterized by erythematous papules and honey-colored crusting.

(Choice B)  The rashes associated with irritant contact dermatitis (eg, from direct contact with chemicals in skin products) are typically erythematous when acute and hyperpigmented and lichenified when chronic.

(Choice C)  Pityriasis alba presents as hypopigmented macules/patches that do not tan.  However, the lesions have indistinct margins, unlike this patient's well-demarcated macules, making this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice E)  In vitiligo, affected areas would not tan with sun exposure and are depigmented (ie, white), not hypopigmented.  In addition, scaling and pruritus are not seen.

Educational objective:
Tinea versicolor is a superficial fungal skin infection characterized by hyperpigmented, hypopigmented, or erythematous macules on the upper trunk and extremities.  The diagnosis is usually clinical, and treatment includes topical selenium sulfide or ketoconazole.

(Choice B)  The rashes associated with irritant contact dermatitis (eg, from direct contact with chemicals in skin products) are typically erythematous when acute and hyperpigmented and lichenified when chronic.

(Choice C)  Pityriasis alba presents as hypopigmented macules/patches that do not tan.  However, the lesions have indistinct margins, unlike this patient's well-demarcated macules, making this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice E)  In vitiligo, affected areas would not tan with sun exposure and are depigmented (ie, white), not hypopigmented.  In addition, scaling and pruritus are not seen.

Educational objective:
Tinea versicolor is a superficial fungal skin infection characterized by hyperpigmented, hypopigmented, or erythematous macules on the upper trunk and extremities.  The diagnosis is usually clinical, and treatment includes topical selenium sulfide or ketoconazole.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Pediatrics

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 17-year-old boy has a rash that has been present for a month.  Multiple light patches appeared on the patient's face, chest, back, and arms while he attended a week-long swim camp.  The patient bought a new sunscreen to prevent burning and applied it 30 minutes before swimming in the camp's pool.  The spots did not tan even though the surrounding skin did somewhat.  The patient says the spots are mildly pruritic but not painful.  Vital signs are normal.  The rash is shown in the exhibit.  Some spots have slight scaling and are nontender.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor)

Pathogenesis

  • Superficial skin infection by Malassezia species
  • Commensal fungus converts to pathogenic filamentous form with exposure to hot & humid environments

Clinical features

  • Hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous macules
  • Distribution: trunk & upper extremities in adolescents & adults, face in children
  • ± Fine scale, pruritus

Diagnosis

  • Clinical
  • KOH preparation: hyphae & yeast cells in a spaghetti-&-meatballs pattern

Treatment

  • Topical ketoconazole, terbinafine, or selenium sulfide

KOH = potassium hydroxide.

This patient has a well-demarcated, hypopigmented rash on the upper trunk that does not tan with sun exposure, a presentation consistent with tinea versicolor.  Tinea versicolor is a superficial skin infection caused by Malasseziaspecies.  These fungi convert to pathogenic forms with heat and humidity; transient melanocyte damage to affected areas results in tanning of only surrounding areas with sun exposure, most apparent in the summer.

TV manifests as well-demarcated macules that can be hyperpigmented, hypopigmented, or erythematous (hence the name "versicolor"); they may coalesce and are often covered with fine scales.  Tinea versicolor commonly affects the upper trunk and extremities, likely due to higher sebum production of these areas, and mild pruritus can occur.  The diagnosis of tinea versicolor is often clinical but can be confirmed with potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scrapings showing hyphae and yeast (spaghetti-and-meatballs appearance).

Management includes topical ketoconazole, which has a direct antifungal effect by limiting the production of a fungal cell membrane component via inhibition of a cytochrome P450 enzyme.  Alternate therapies include topical selenium sulfide or terbinafine.

(Choice A)  Impetigo is a superficial bacterial infection characterized by erythematous papules and honey-colored crusting.

(Choice B)  The rashes associated with irritant contact dermatitis (eg, from direct contact with chemicals in skin products) are typically erythematous when acute and hyperpigmented and lichenified when chronic.

(Choice C)  Pityriasis alba presents as hypopigmented macules/patches that do not tan.  However, the lesions have indistinct margins, unlike this patient's well-demarcated macules, making this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice E)  In vitiligo, affected areas would not tan with sun exposure and are depigmented (ie, white), not hypopigmented.  In addition, scaling and pruritus are not seen.

Educational objective:
Tinea versicolor is a superficial fungal skin infection characterized by hyperpigmented, hypopigmented, or erythematous macules on the upper trunk and extremities.  The diagnosis is usually clinical, and treatment includes topical selenium sulfide or ketoconazole.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Pediatrics

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 7-year-old boy is evaluated due to hair loss.  For the past few weeks, the patient has had worsening hair loss in patches on the scalp.  There is no associated pain or itching.  Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient's height and weight have consistently tracked at around the 30th percentile for his age.  He has achieved developmental milestones within the normal range and has had no significant academic concerns at school.  Skin examination findings are shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hair loss?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Alopecia areata

Pathogenesis

  • Autoimmune attack on hair bulb cells
  • Associated with other autoimmune disorders (eg, hypo/hyperthyroidism, vitiligo)

Clinical presentation

  • Diagnosis made by visual inspection (eg, with dermatoscope)
  • Painless, patchy, nonscarring hair loss affecting scalp, face, or body
  • Exclamation point hairs (small hairs with proximal tapering) may be seen

Management

  • Mild/moderate hair loss: intralesional or topical corticosteroid therapy
  • Extensive hair loss: oral Janus kinase inhibitor (eg, baricitinib) or topical immunotherapy (eg, diphenylcyclopropenone)
  • Screen for autoimmune thyroid disease (serum TSH)

Prognosis

  • Regrowth is common in mild cases
  • Recurrence is common

This patient has patchy, painless hair loss consistent with alopecia areata.  Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disorder that can affect the hair bulb cells on any part of the body and develops over weeks in discrete patches with normal underlying scalp or skin (eg, no erythema or scarring).  Hair follicles are preserved in alopecia areata (ie, nonscarring alopecia), making hair regrowth possible.  Alopecia areata may occur in isolation but can also be associated with other autoimmune conditions (eg, vitiligo, autoimmune thyroid disease).

The diagnosis of alopecia areata is usually based on visual inspection.  Close inspection (eg, using a dermatoscope) may show narrowing of hair shafts close to the skin surface (exclamation point hairs), which are reflective of the shaft weakening caused by bulb inflammation.  In contrast, normal hair shafts are thicker at the skin surface.  The hair pull test is often positive as well (ie, when a cluster of ~50 hair fibers is pulled firmly, extraction of >5 or 6 strands is abnormal).  Treatment includes topical or intralesional corticosteroids.  A recurring course of disease is common, but most patients have regrowth over time.

(Choice B)  Discoid lupus erythematosus of the scalp causes scarring (permanent) hair loss.  Hyper- or hypopigmented scaly plaques are often present on the scalp, in addition to the face and neck; these features are absent in this patient.

(Choice C)  Pediculosis capitis (head lice infestation) presents with pruritus of the scalp and visible nits.  It is not typically associated with hair loss.

(Choice D)  Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection of the scalp that presents as a scaly patch of hair loss.  When the infection affects the hair shaft, small, black dots representing broken shafts can also be seen on the scalp.  This patient has a normal-appearing scalp, inconsistent with tinea capitis.

(Choice E)  Trichotillomania is compulsive hair-pulling that results in patchy alopecia and hair shafts of variable lengths of regrowth, a finding not present in this patient.

Educational objective:
Alopecia areata is characterized by patchy and largely asymptomatic hair loss with normal underlying scalp or skin.  The diagnosis is based on visual inspection.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Pediatrics

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 36-year-old man has a 2-day history of a rash on his lower back and side.  The symptoms began with itching and burning pain, followed by the eruption of small, red papules.  He has never had similar symptoms.  The patient's medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, which is being treated with infliximab.  On physical examination, there is an erythematous rash, as shown in the exhibit.  The rest of the skin examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's condition?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
This patient has an erythematous rash suggestive of herpes zoster (shingles), which is caused by reactivation of a latent varicella-zoster virus infection.  The rash typically begins with small papules that can become confluent and evolve into vesicles or bullae with subsequent crusting after 7-10 days.  The rash is usually limited to a single dermatome but may involve adjacent dermatomes; a few scattered lesions may develop in distant areas.  Most patients have associated neuritic symptoms, including pain, itching, burning, and allodynia, which may precede the onset of a visible rash.

Age and immunocompromised status predispose individuals to shingles.  This patient likely developed shingles due to infliximab therapy (tumor necrosis factor-alpha inhibitor).  Treatment with antiviral agents (eg, acyclovir, famciclovir, valacyclovir) decreases the duration of symptoms and the incidence of postherpetic neuralgia, especially if initiated within 72 hours of the onset of symptoms.

(Choice A)  Tinea corporis is characterized by pruritic, annular plaques with a scaly border and central clearing.  It is treated with topical antifungals (eg, clotrimazole, terbinafine).

(Choice B)  Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic used to treat superficial skin infections such as impetigo, which presents with small vesicles with a yellow exudate and honey-colored crust.  Mupirocin is also used to eradicate methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus colonization from the nares.

(Choice C)  Topical 5-fluorouracil is used to treat skin conditions caused by rapid cell division, such as actinic keratoses and superficial basal cell carcinomas.  These lesions are typically hyperkeratotic and do not normally occur in a dermatomal distribution.

(Choice D)  Topical glucocorticoids are used to treat various inflammatory skin conditions such as contact dermatitis, which presents with erythematous papules and vesicles but is usually extremely pruritic and is more common on exposed skin.

Educational objective:
Herpes zoster is a painful reactivation of the varicella zoster virus that causes a vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution.  Antiviral agents (eg, acyclovir, valacyclovir) may be used to decrease the duration of disease and the incidence of postherpetic neuralgia.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Family medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 36-year-old man is evaluated due to a 2-day history of a rash on his lower back.  The symptoms began with itching and burning pain, followed by the eruption of small, red papules.  He has not had similar symptoms in the past.  The patient's medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, which is currently being treated with infliximab.  Vital signs are normal.  On physical examination, there is an erythematous rash, as shown in the exhibit.  The rest of the skin examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's condition?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Herpes zoster (shingles)

Pathogenesis

  • Reactivation of varicella-zoster virus from sensory nerve ganglion
  • Risk factors: increasing age, immunosuppression

Clinical features

  • Prodrome: itching, tingling, burning in dermatomal distribution
  • Rash: grouped papules & vesicles on erythematous base; ulceration & crusting; acute neuritic pain

Treatment

  • Antiviral therapy (eg, valacyclovir)

Complications

  • Postherpetic neuralgia (most common)
  • Herpes zoster ophthalmicus
  • Herpes zoster oticus (Ramsay Hunt syndrome)

This patient has an erythematous rash suggestive of herpes zoster (shingles), which is caused by reactivation of latent varicella zoster virus infection.  The rash typically begins with small papules that can eventually become confluent and evolve into vesicles or bullae, with subsequent crusting in 7-10 days.  The rash is usually limited to a single dermatome, but may involve adjacent dermatomes; a few scattered lesions may develop in distant areas.  Most patients will have associated neuritic symptoms, including pain, itching, burning, and allodynia, which may precede the onset of a visible rash.

Age and immunocompromised status predispose to shingles.  This patient likely developed shingles due to infliximab therapy (tumor necrosis factor-α inhibitor).  Treatment with antiviral agents (eg, acyclovir, famciclovir, valacyclovir) decreases the duration of symptoms and the incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia, especially if initiated within 72 hours of the onset of symptoms.

(Choice A)  Tinea corporis is characterized by pruritic, annular plaques with a scaly border and central clearing.  It is treated with topical antifungals (eg, clotrimazole, terbinafine).

(Choice B)  Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic used to treat superficial skin infections such as impetigo, which presents with small vesicles with a yellow exudate and honey-colored crust.  It is also used to eradicate methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus colonization from the nares.

(Choice C)  Topical 5-fluorouracil is used to treat skin conditions caused by rapid cell division, such as actinic keratoses and superficial basal cell carcinomas.  These lesions are typically hyperkeratotic and do not normally occur in a dermatomal distribution.

(Choice D)  Topical glucocorticoids are used to treat various inflammatory skin conditions, such as contact dermatitis, which presents with erythematous papules and vesicles but is usually extremely pruritic and is more common on exposed skin.

Educational objective:
Herpes zoster is a painful reactivation of the varicella zoster virus that causes a vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution.  Acyclovir and other antivirals may be used to decrease the duration of disease and the incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 73-year-old woman has had thickening and discoloration of multiple toenails in both feet over the past 8 months.  The patient has had no associated pain but frequently snags her stockings on the nails.  Medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension.  Examination findings are as shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
This patient has extensive thickening and discoloration of the toenails consistent with onychomycosis.  Onychomycosis is a chronic dermatophyte infection of the nails most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum and similar fungi.  The same organisms can also cause tinea pedis, manifesting with itching, erythema (as seen in this patient), and scaling in the skin of the interdigital spaces and surrounding foot.

Onychomycosis is typically painless, but the thickening and roughness of the nails may cause problems with stockings and footwear.  In addition, fissuring of the surrounding skin may allow the entry of bacteria, leading to paronychia or cellulitis.  The diagnosis is confirmed by potassium hydroxide microscopy of nail scrapings.  Several topical and oral antifungal agents (eg, terbinafine) are effective, but prolonged treatment (eg, 12 weeks) may be necessary; treatment failure is common.

(Choice A)  Onychomycosis due to yeasts (eg, Candida species) is usually seen in the fingernails, often in patients who have chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis or frequently work in wet conditions.  Yeast onychomycosis is uncommon in the toenails.

(Choice B)  Involvement of the nails by lichen planus produces longitudinal ridges, fissuring, and thinning, not thickening, of the nail plate.

(Choice C)  Pseudomonas aeruginosa can colonize the nail plate and is often seen in patients with underlying onychomycosis due to fracturing and increased porosity of the nail.  When this infection occurs, it typically produces a characteristic green discoloration (chloronychia).

(Choice D)  Psoriasis of the nail presents with nail pitting, oil spots, and separation of the nail plate from the nail bed (onycholysis).

Educational objective:
Onychomycosis is a chronic dermatophyte infection of the nails most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum and similar fungi.  It is characterized by nail thickening, roughness, and discoloration.  The diagnosis is confirmed by potassium hydroxide microscopy of nail scrapings.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 73-year-old woman is seen for thickening and discoloration of multiple toenails on both feet over the past 8 months.  The patient has had no associated pain but frequently snags her stockings on the nails.  Medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension.  The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol.  Examination findings are shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
This patient has extensive thickening and discoloration of the toenails consistent with onychomycosis.  Onychomycosis is a chronic dermatophyte infection of the nails most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum and similar fungi.  The same organisms can also cause tinea pedis, manifesting with itching, erythema (as seen in this patient), and scaling of the skin in the interdigital spaces and on the surrounding foot.

(Choice C)  Pseudomonas aeruginosa can colonize the nail plate and is often seen in patients with underlying onychomycosis due to fracturing and increased porosity of the nail.  When this infection occurs, it typically produces a characteristic green discoloration (chloronychia).

(Choice D)  Psoriasis of the nail presents with nail pitting, oil spots, and separation of the nail plate from the nail bed (onycholysis).

Onychomycosis is a chronic dermatophyte infection of the nails most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum and similar fungi.  It is characterized by nail thickening, roughness, and discoloration.  The diagnosis is confirmed by potassium hydroxide microscopy of nail scrapings.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Family medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 15-year-old, previously healthy girl comes in due to spots on her face.  About a year ago, the patient started noticing tiny bumps on the forehead; they have progressively increased in number and size.  She has used several over-the-counter facial cleansing products without relief.  Physical examination shows an oily complexion and the findings seen in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
This patient has noninflammatory, comedonal acne on the forehead; the treatment of choice is a topical retinoid.  The pathogenesis of acne involves the following:

  • Hyperkeratinization leads to keratin plug formation in the hair follicles, preventing sebum flow from the follicles to the skin surface.  When the keratin plug is hidden under the skin, as in this patient, it is called a closed comedo.  In contrast, when the keratin plug is exposed at the follicular orifice, it is called an open comedo; melanin and oxidized sebum give open comedones a dark color.  Comedo formation (ie, comedogenesis) is the initial step in acne pathogenesis.

  • Cutibacterium acnes, which is part of the skin flora, relies on sebum as a nutrient source.  As the bacteria proliferate, they trigger an inflammatory response that leads to the formation of the red papules and pustules seen in inflammatory acne.

  • Ongoing inflammation leads to follicle rupture, releasing additional proinflammatory substances and leading to the formation of nodulocystic acne.

Topical retinoids inhibit comedogenesis by normalizing keratinization; decreasing epithelial cohesiveness, which facilitates desquamation and prevents follicular plugging; and increasing epithelial turnover, which facilitates the extrusion of comedones.  Because retinoids inhibit comedogenesis, the first step in acne pathogenesis, they are also used as a part of multiagent therapy for inflammatory acne.

(Choice A)  Patients with oily skin are generally advised to use water- or gel-based cleansers.  Cream-based cleansers contain higher oil content and are comedogenic.

(Choice B)  Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives have an antiandrogenic effect that inhibits sebum production.  They are commonly used for women with moderate/severe inflammatory acne, especially those who have premenstrual acne flares.  However, oral contraceptives are not recommended for noninflammatory, comedonal acne.

(Choice C)  Systemic antibiotics (eg, tetracyclines) effective against C acnes are used to treat moderate/severe inflammatory acne or acne that is widespread (eg, on the back), making the application of topical therapy impractical.

(Choice D)  Topical corticosteroids are used in a variety of inflammatory dermatoses (eg, contact dermatitis) but are not indicated for acne.  The inflammation seen in acne is triggered by C acnes; therefore, antibiotics, not steroids, are part of the multiagent regimen for inflammatory acne.

Educational objective:
Topical retinoids are first-line treatment for noninflammatory, comedonal acne.  They inhibit comedogenesis by normalizing keratinization, decreasing epithelial cohesiveness, and increasing epithelial turnover.

newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Pediatrics

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: An 18-month-old girl presents with a rash and blisters that started this morning.  Yesterday, the child was very fussy, particularly when her parents picked her up.  This morning, the girl developed erythema and peeling skin around her mouth, axillae, and inguinal areas.  Temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 89/52 mm Hg, and pulse is 145/min.  Superficial flaccid bullae and an erythematous rash are diffusely distributed over the body.  Slight focal pressure to the back results in sloughing of the top layer of skin with underlying erythema.  The face appears edematous, with perioral crusting.  A single pustule is noted under the left naris, but no mucosal lesions are seen.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

Pathogenesis

  • Disseminated Staphylococcus aureus exfoliative toxin

Risk factors

  • Children: age ≤5
  • Adults: renal insufficiency, immunosuppression

Clinical
features

  • Prodrome: fever, irritability
  • Cutaneous manifestations
    • Generalized, tender erythema
    • Flaccid blisters
    • Superficial desquamation (Nikolsky sign)
  • No mucosal involvement

Management

  • IV antistaphylococcal antibiotic (eg, nafcillin, vancomycin)
  • Supportive care (eg, fluids, wound care)

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is a blistering skin condition most commonly found in infants and young children.  The pathogenesis involves infection with certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus that produce exfoliative toxins, which disrupt keratinocyte adhesion in the superficial epidermis.

Clinical presentation begins with a prodrome of fever, irritability, and skin tenderness.  Generalized erythema is then followed by flaccid blisters/bullae located predominantly in flexural areas exposed to mechanical pressure (eg, axillae, groin).  Although perioral crusting can occur, mucosal surfaces are typically spared.  Gentle pressure on the skin surface causes detachment of a superficial layer of skin (ie, Nikolsky sign), and epidermal shedding exposes underlying erythematous skin with a scalded appearance.

In neonates, the source of infection is often the umbilicus or circumcision site, whereas in older children, there may be nasopharyngeal colonization or a primary skin lesion (eg, pustule), as seen in this patient.  Cultures from the blood and potential infectious sources are obtained; however, the diagnosis is generally clinical, and intact bullae are usually sterile.  Treatment involves antistaphylococcal antibiotics (eg, nafcillin, vancomycin) and supportive wound care for denuded areas.  The mortality rate is low in children, and symptoms typically resolve in 1-2 weeks.

(Choice A)  Bullous impetigo is a localized form of SSSS also caused by exfoliative toxin–producing S aureus.  Unlike this case, patients with bullous impetigo typically appear well and have blisters confined to the primary area of infection.  In addition, Nikolsky sign would be negative.

(Choice B)  Erythema multiforme is a self-limited reaction to certain infections (eg, herpes simplex virus) that manifests as targetoid lesions.  The lesions may have central bullae, but Nikolsky sign is negative.

(Choice C)  Scarlet fever, caused by erythrogenic toxin–producing strains of group A Streptococcus, presents with a fine, pink, sandpaper-like rash following an episode of pharyngitis in children.  The rash is prominent in flexural areas and often desquamates but does not cause blistering or a positive Nikolsky sign.

(Choice E)  Toxic epidermal necrolysis manifests as extensive (>30% body surface area) skin blistering and erosion; it is typically triggered by a medication.  Nikolsky sign is positive; however, mucous membrane involvement is expected with this condition but is not seen in this patient.

Educational objective:
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by exfoliative toxin–producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus and typically occurs in infants and young children.  A prodrome of fever, irritability, and skin tenderness is followed by generalized erythema, superficial flaccid blisters, and epidermal shedding with light pressure (ie, Nikolsky sign).

newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Pediatrics

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: An 18-month-old girl presents with a rash and blisters that started this morning.  Yesterday, the child was very fussy, particularly when her parents picked her up.  This morning, the girl developed erythema and peeling skin around her mouth, axillae, and inguinal areas.  Temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 89/52 mm Hg, and pulse is 145/min.  Superficial flaccid bullae and an erythematous rash are diffusely distributed over the body.  Slight focal pressure to the back results in sloughing of the top layer of skin with underlying erythema.  The face appears edematous, with perioral crusting.  A single pustule is noted under the left naris, but no mucosal lesions are seen.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

Pathogenesis

  • Disseminated Staphylococcus aureus exfoliative toxin

Risk factors

  • Children: age ≤5
  • Adults: renal insufficiency, immunosuppression

Clinical
features

  • Prodrome: fever, irritability
  • Cutaneous manifestations
    • Generalized, tender erythema
    • Flaccid blisters
    • Superficial desquamation (Nikolsky sign)
  • No mucosal involvement

Management

  • IV antistaphylococcal antibiotic (eg, nafcillin, vancomycin)
  • Supportive care (eg, fluids, wound care)

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is a blistering skin condition most commonly found in infants and young children.  The pathogenesis involves infection with certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus that produce exfoliative toxins, which disrupt keratinocyte adhesion in the superficial epidermis.

Clinical presentation begins with a prodrome of fever, irritability, and skin tenderness.  Generalized erythema is then followed by flaccid blisters/bullae located predominantly in flexural areas exposed to mechanical pressure (eg, axillae, groin).  Although perioral crusting can occur, mucosal surfaces are typically spared.  Gentle pressure on the skin surface causes detachment of a superficial layer of skin (ie, Nikolsky sign), and epidermal shedding exposes underlying erythematous skin with a scalded appearance.

In neonates, the source of infection is often the umbilicus or circumcision site, whereas in older children, there may be nasopharyngeal colonization or a primary skin lesion (eg, pustule), as seen in this patient.  Cultures from the blood and potential infectious sources are obtained; however, the diagnosis is generally clinical, and intact bullae are usually sterile.  Treatment involves antistaphylococcal antibiotics (eg, nafcillin, vancomycin) and supportive wound care for denuded areas.  The mortality rate is low in children, and symptoms typically resolve in 1-2 weeks.

(Choice A)  Bullous impetigo is a localized form of SSSS also caused by exfoliative toxin–producing S aureus.  Unlike this case, patients with bullous impetigo typically appear well and have blisters confined to the primary area of infection.  In addition, Nikolsky sign would be negative.

(Choice B)  Erythema multiforme is a self-limited reaction to certain infections (eg, herpes simplex virus) that manifests as targetoid lesions.  The lesions may have central bullae, but Nikolsky sign is negative.

(Choice C)  Scarlet fever, caused by erythrogenic toxin–producing strains of group A Streptococcus, presents with a fine, pink, sandpaper-like rash following an episode of pharyngitis in children.  The rash is prominent in flexural areas and often desquamates but does not cause blistering or a positive Nikolsky sign.

(Choice E)  Toxic epidermal necrolysis manifests as extensive (>30% body surface area) skin blistering and erosion; it is typically triggered by a medication.  Nikolsky sign is positive; however, mucous membrane involvement is expected with this condition but is not seen in this patient.

Educational objective:
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by exfoliative toxin–producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus and typically occurs in infants and young children.  A prodrome of fever, irritability, and skin tenderness is followed by generalized erythema, superficial flaccid blisters, and epidermal shedding with light pressure (ie, Nikolsky sign).

newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Pediatrics

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText:
A 60-year-old woman is seen due to progressive pain, swelling, and redness of the left leg for 4 days.  She has had no obvious trauma or insect bites to the affected area.  She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis.  Temperature is 39.4 C (102.9 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 106/min, and respirations are 18/min.  The patient appears well.  Her left anterior leg is swollen, erythematous, tender, and warm to the touch over a 10 × 5 cm region, as shown in the exhibit.  The erythema is present throughout the affected area and has flat, poorly demarcated edges.  There is no overlying crepitus or bullae.  The left thigh and right leg are normal in appearance.  The remainder of the examination is normal.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin14.0 g/dL
Platelets222,000/mm3
Leukocytes15,500/mm3
Neutrophils86%
Lymphocytes14%

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Common skin infections

Infection

Organism

Manifestations

Erysipelas

  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Superficial dermis & lymphatics
  • Raised, sharply demarcated edges
  • Rapid spread & onset
  • Fever early in course

Cellulitis
(nonpurulent)

  • S pyogenes
  • MSSA
  • Deep dermis & subcutaneous fat
  • Flat edges with poor demarcation
  • Indolent (over days)
  • Localized (fever later in course)

Cellulitis
(purulent)

  • MSSA
  • MRSA
  • Purulent drainage
  • Folliculitis: infected hair follicle
  • Furuncles: folliculitis → dermis → abscess
  • Carbuncle: multiple furuncles

MRSA = methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus;MSSA = methicillin-sensitive S aureus.

Cellulitis is a skin infection of the deep dermis and subcutaneous fat usually caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococcus (nonpurulent) or Staphylococcus aureus (purulent).  Infections take root in areas of skin disruption (eg, insect bite, toe-web impetigo, stasis edema).  Patients typically develop a slowly spreading rash that is warm, tender, and erythematous with flat, indistinct borders.  Fever and regional lymphangitis/lymphadenitis may be present.  Laboratory studies usually show leukocytosis with a predominance of neutrophils, a characteristic of most acute bacterial infections.  Diagnosis is based largely on clinical findings, but blood cultures may be useful in patients with systemic toxicity, extensive rash, or certain comorbidities (eg, immunocompromised status).

(Choice B)  Deep vein thrombosis may cause calf swelling, erythema, and warmth.  An anterior leg rash, high fever, and leukocytosis are not typical.

(Choice C)  Erysipelas is similar in etiology (generally streptococci) and clinical presentation to cellulitis.  However, erysipelas is limited to the epidermis and superficial dermis, which gives erysipelas its characteristic sharp, raised (vs flat) borders and intense erythema.

(Choice D)  Erythema nodosum is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction usually characterized by subcutaneous, bilateral, anterior leg nodules (inflammation of subcutaneous tissues).  It is associated with infectious (eg, streptococcal pharyngitis), autoimmune (eg, sarcoidosis), or inflammatory processes (eg, inflammatory bowel disease).  This patient has a flat, unilateral skin rash.

(Choice E)  Necrotizing fasciitis is the destructive infection of the fascia and subcutaneous fat marked by severe pain, systemic toxicity, bullae, crepitus, and skin necrosis.

Educational objective:
Cellulitis is a skin infection of the deep dermis and subcutaneous fat that is usually caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococcus (nonpurulent) or Staphylococcus aureus (purulent).  Patients typically develop a slowly spreading rash that is warm, erythematous, and painful with flat, indistinct borders.

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office due to skin lesions on her trunk and proximal upper limbs.  The patient noticed the lesions after returning from a beach vacation a week ago.  During the vacation, she was exposed to the sun on several occasions without prior application of sunscreen.  The lesions are mildly itchy but not painful.  Examination shows hypopigmented lesions as shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor)

Pathogenesis

  • Superficial skin infection by Malassezia species
  • Commensal fungus converts to pathogenic filamentous form with exposure to hot & humid environments

Clinical features

  • Hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous macules
  • Distribution: trunk & upper extremities in adolescents & adults, face in children
  • ± Fine scale, pruritus

Diagnosis

  • Clinical
  • KOH preparation: hyphae & yeast cells in a spaghetti-&-meatballs pattern

Treatment

  • Topical ketoconazole, terbinafine, or selenium sulfide

KOH = potassium hydroxide.

Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor) is a superficial fungal skin infection caused by Malassezia species (nondermatophytic, lipid-dependent yeasts [eg, M globosa, M furfur]).  It is characterized by salmon-colored, hyper- or hypopigmented macules that are sometimes covered by fine scales, most commonly on the upper trunk and extremities.  Hypopigmented areas are frequently noticed following sun exposure due to tanning of the surrounding skin.  Lesions may be itchy.

Potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scrapings shows a "spaghetti and meatballs" appearance with large, blunt hyphae (spaghetti) and thick-walled budding yeast (meatballs).  Topical treatment with selenium sulfide or ketoconazole is recommended, but the pigmentation changes can take months to resolve following treatment.

(Choice A)  Cutaneous candidiasis presents with an erythematous, vesiculopapular rash in warm, moist areas (eg, skinfolds).  It is often associated with recent antibiotic use or immunocompromised states (eg, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus).

(Choice B)  Irritant contact dermatitis is caused by physical or chemical irritation, most commonly due to soaps, solvents, acids, or alkalis.  It presents with erythema and fissuring, usually on the hands.

(Choice C)  Tinea corporis (ringworm) is a dermatophyte infection that presents as annular lesions with advancing scaly borders and central clearing or as scaly patches over the trunk.  Other dermatophyte infections include tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea cruris (jock itch), and tinea capitis (scalp ringworm).  Tinea versicolor is the only tinea infection that is not caused by dermatophytes, which require keratin for growth.

(Choice E)  Vitiligo is characterized by complete depigmentation (from melanocyte destruction, possibly due to autoimmune mechanisms).  However, it most commonly affects the face and hands and does not cause pruritus.

Educational objective:
Tinea versicolor, a superficial nondermatophyte fungal skin infection caused by Malassezia species, is characterized by salmon-colored, hyper- or hypopigmented macules.  The diagnosis is confirmed with potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scrapings, and treatment is with topical antifungals.

(Choice D)  Tinea corporis (ringworm) presents as annular lesions with advancing scaly borders and central clearing or as scaly patches over the trunk.  Other dermatophyte infections include tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea cruris (jock itch), and tinea capitis (scalp ringworm).  Tinea versicolor is the only tinea infection that is not caused by dermatophytes (which require keratin for growth).

Educational objective:
Tinea versicolor is a superficial nondermatophyte fungal skin infection caused by Malassezia species and characterized by salmon-colored, hyper- or hypopigmented macules.  The diagnosis is confirmed with potassium hydroxide preparation of skin scrapings, and treatment is with topical antifungals.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Medicine

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: An 11-year-old boy is brought in by his parents due to a pruritic rash that started 2 weeks ago on his hands and subsequently spread to other sites.  The patient's mother reports that he is constantly scratching and that his sleep is now disturbed due to intense pruritus.  A cousin who recently shared a room with him had similar symptoms.  The patient has had no fever and is up to date with routine vaccinations.  Physical examination shows numerous scattered 2- to 3-mm erythematous papules and vesicles with excoriations on the hands, feet, scrotum, and waistline.  Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention in management of this patient?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Scabies

Pathogenesis

  • Sarcoptes scabiei mite infestation
  • Spread by direct person-to-person contact

Clinical features

  • Extremely pruritic, small, erythematous papules
  • Distribution: interdigital web spaces, flexor wrists, extensor elbows, axillae, feet, umbilicus & genitalia
  • Burrows (thin serpiginous lines) may not be visible but pathognomonic if present

Diagnosis

  • Clinical
  • Skin scraping with microscopy is confirmatory

Treatment

  • Topical 5% permethrin OR oral ivermectin
  • Treat household members & close personal contacts
  • Environmental measures (eg, launder clothing/bedding)

Scabies, caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei, is characterized by an intensely pruritic rash classically located in the periumbilical area, genitalia, and interdigital web spaces of the hands and feet.  The rash consists of small, erythematous papules or vesicles, as well as pathognomonic burrows (ie, <1-cm lines on the skin) caused by female mites burrowing into the epidermis to lay eggs.  Burrows may not be visualized due to excoriation.

Scabies is spread by direct person-to-person contact; this patient's recent contact with an individual displaying similar symptoms supports the diagnosis, which is usually clinical.  First-line treatment is topical permethrin or oral ivermectin.  Because of the lengthy incubation period (3-6 weeks), household contacts should be treated even if asymptomatic because they may have active infection before the characteristic rash develops.  Measures to reduce fomite transmission include laundering recently used clothing and bedding.

(Choice A)  Oral acyclovir can treat varicella in patients at risk for complications (eg, adolescents, patients with immunocompromised status).  Unlike this case, varicella presents with a prodrome (eg, fever, malaise) followed by successive crops of diffuse, intensely pruritic vesicles that crust over within 1-2 weeks.

(Choice B)  Oral clindamycin can treat extensive impetigo, a superficial bacterial infection of the skin.  Erythematous papules or vesicles is typical, but an overlying honey-colored crust is also expected.

(Choice C)  Supportive care is appropriate for hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with fever, oral lesions, and a maculopapular/vesicular rash on the palms and soles; the rash is typically nonpruritic and resolves within a week.  This patient's rash duration, intense pruritus, and lack of systemic symptoms make HFMD unlikely.

(Choice D)  Topical corticosteroids (eg, hydrocortisone) can relieve symptoms of poison ivy dermatitis and bedbug infestations.  Poison ivy causes intense pruritus, but lesions are often linear.  Bedbug bites present as pruritic, erythematous papules; however, the rash usually affects exposed areas, not typically the genitalia.  Corticosteroids can help with pruritus in scabies, but eradicating the infestation with permethrin is the priority.

Educational objective:
Scabies is an intensely pruritic rash characterized by small, erythematous papules/vesicles in the periumbilical area, genitalia, and interdigital web spaces.  Treatment is topical permethrin or oral ivermectin.
newExamYearQuestionList.subject: Pediatrics

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 52-year-old man is seen for an enlarging rash at the left ankle and upper back.  The rash began 6 weeks ago and is associated with significant itching.  The patient has tried topical antihistamines and calamine lotion without relief.  Medical history is otherwise unremarkable.  Temperature is 36.9 C (98.4 F), blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 12/min.  BMI is 25 kg/m2.  Examination shows a rash on the back, as seen in the exhibit, and a similar rash is noted at the ankle.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Tinea corporis (ringworm)

Risk factors

  • Athletes who have skin-to-skin contact
  • Humid environment
  • Contact with infected animals (eg, rodents)

Presentation

  • Scaly, erythematous, pruritic patch with centrifugal spread
  • Subsequent central clearing with raised, annular border

Treatment

  • First-line/localized: topical antifungal (eg, clotrimazole, terbinafine)
  • Second-line/extensive: oral antifungal (eg, terbinafine, griseofulvin)

This patient has a pruritic rash with a scaly, erythematous border and partial central clearing, findings consistent with tinea corporis (ringworm).  Tinea corporis is a cutaneous dermatophyte infection most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum.  Tinea corporis patches (or plaques) are typically annular but may become confluent to form a flower petal shape.

Patients with tinea corporis often have concurrent infection elsewhere on the body, hands (tinea manuum), and groin (tinea cruris) or between the toes or on the sides of the feet (tinea pedis).  Patients with immunocompromising conditions (eg, HIV, diabetes mellitus) can have severe or widespread disease.  Other risk factors include exposure to warm, moist areas (eg, public showers, swimming pools), contact with infected animals or people (eg, during sports participation), and tight or occlusive clothing.

The diagnosis is confirmed using a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation of skin scrapings.  Most patients can be treated with topical antifungals (eg, terbinafine, clotrimazole); when topical management fails or extensive disease is present, the patient may need systemic therapy (eg, oral terbinafine, fluconazole).

(Choice A)  Erythema marginatum is a manifestation of acute rheumatic fever characterized by numerous widespread plaques with a sharp, annular or serpiginous border and central clearing.  It is transient, nonpruritic, and most common in children.

(Choice B)  Erythema migrans is a target-shaped rash that is the cardinal manifestation of Lyme disease.  The lesions are not scaly and do not have a raised border.  Patients frequently have systemic symptoms (eg, myalgias, fatigue) and a history of exposure to ticks in an endemic area.

(Choice C)  Nummular eczema is a chronic, relapsing/remitting condition that presents with erythematous, pruritic, coin-shaped patches on the extremities.  The lesions may initially have a scant exudate and are uncommon on the back and upper trunk.

(Choice D)  Pityriasis rosea is characterized by numerous small, oval, scaly plaques, often with an initial lesion (herald patch) that is much larger than the later lesions.  It is typically seen in children and young adults, and it usually occurs on the trunk and proximal (not distal) extremities.  In addition, the rash typically resolves within 6 weeks of presentation.

Educational objective:
Tinea corporis is a cutaneous dermatophyte infection that causes a pruritic rash with a scaly, erythematous border and central clearing.  Patients often have concurrent infection elsewhere on the body, hands, groin, or feet.  Those with immunocompromising conditions (eg, HIV, diabetes mellitus) can have severe or widespread disease.
